program.title: HubSpot Technical Training Program
program.description: This training program uses realistic client scenarios to progressively build HubSpot implementation skills. Each module presents a complete business case with specific requirements that must be solved through HubSpot configuration.
program.philosophy: Learning happens through doing. You'll understand client needs, design solutions, implement in HubSpot, and document your work for handoff. You'll make decisions about property structures, workflow logic, and automation design - just like real consulting work.
program.prerequisites: Basic familiarity with CRM concepts (contacts, deals, companies). Access to HubSpot Professional or Enterprise sandbox portal.

phases.title: Phase 1: Foundations
phases.description: Modules 1-3 build your foundational HubSpot skills through a progressive gym client scenario.
phases.milestoneReview:
Schedule a meeting to present all three modules
Format: 45-60 minute review session

- 30 min: Walk through your implementations
- 15-30 min: Q&A and design critique

What I'm Looking For:
- Do your solutions actually solve the client problems?
- Can you articulate why you made specific design choices?
- Did you think through edge cases?
- Is your documentation clear enough for client handoff?
- Are you making decisions independently or just following instructions?
phases.passCriteria:
- All core functionality works
- You can explain your design decisions confidently
- Edge cases are handled (even if solution is "flag for manual review")
- Documentation exists and is usable

modules.clientStory:
LocalFit Gym is a small fitness studio in downtown Austin run by Sarah Martinez. She's been running the business for 3 years and currently tracks her 100 members in a combination of Excel spreadsheets and sticky notes. People sign up for classes through a Google Form, but Sarah has to manually email everyone.

Sarah offers three membership types: Monthly ($150/month), Annual ($1,400/year), and Drop-In ($25/class). She teaches four main class types: Yoga, Spin, CrossFit, and Pilates.

Sarah's Pain Points:
- "I spend an hour every morning organizing emails and forms"
- "I can never remember which members prefer which classes"
- "When someone fills out the interest form, I don't see it until I check email"
- "I have no easy way to email just my yoga members or just my annual members"

What Sarah Wants:
- A single place to see all member information organized
- Automatic categorization by membership type and class interests
- Professional website form with instant notification
- Ability to easily pull up lists like "all active members" or "everyone interested in yoga"
modules.assignment:
Set up Sarah's first CRM. She's not technical, so everything needs to be simple and clearly labeled.

Goals:
- Organize contact data with appropriate properties
- Build a website form that captures the right information
- Create automated workflow when forms are submitted
- Build lists for segmentation
- Ensure Sarah can find and use everything easily

Key Decisions You'll Make:
- Which properties are needed and how to structure them (dropdown vs checkbox vs text?)
- How to organize properties for Sarah's workflow
- What should happen automatically when someone submits the form?
- What lists does Sarah need day-to-day?
modules.testingRequirements:
Before your presentation, test:
- Create 10 test contacts with varied data
- Submit your form and verify all automations trigger
- Check that lists update dynamically
- Verify Sarah would immediately understand how to use this
modules.deliverablesAndPresentation:
Prepare:
- Configured HubSpot portal ready to demo
- Brief documentation explaining how Sarah uses this day-to-day
- Notes on design decisions

Present (15 min):
- Show where properties are organized and why
- Walk through form submission and what happens
- Demonstrate how Sarah would use lists
- Explain one thing you'd improve with more time
modules.beReadyToAnswer:
- "What happens when someone submits the form?"
- "Why did you organize properties that way?"
- "How would Sarah email all her yoga members?"

modules.clientStory:
LocalFit Gym - Three Months Later

Sarah is thrilled with the contact organization, but business is growing. She's now converting 3-5 leads to members every week and losing track of where people are in the sales process.

Current Manual Process:
1. Lead submits free class form
2. Sarah emails to schedule trial
3. They attend trial (or no-show)
4. Sarah follows up to ask if they want to join
5. They either become a member or decline

Sarah's New Pain Points:
- "I have 15 people in process and can't remember who I've followed up with"
- "I schedule trials but don't have a good reminder system"
- "When someone becomes a member, I forget steps in the onboarding"
- "I want to know why people say no so I can improve"

What Sarah Wants:
- Visual pipeline showing where every potential member is
- Automatic contact updates when someone becomes a member
- Automated trial class reminders
- Tracking for why she loses deals
- Weekly pipeline summary

modules.clientStory:
LocalFit Gym - Six Months Later

Sarah hired her first employee - Marcus, her new sales rep. They're getting 15-20 leads per week. Both Sarah and Marcus are following up on the same leads, sometimes reaching out to people who aren't that interested while missing high-quality prospects.

Current Chaos:
- Lead fills out form → both see it → confusion about who follows up
- Someone who downloaded a class schedule gets the same aggressive follow-up as someone who requested a trial
- Sarah notices people who live nearby convert way better, but there's no system to prioritize them
- Marcus spends time on leads that go nowhere while Sarah chases hot prospects

Business Context:
- LocalFit is in downtown Austin (78701)
- People within 3 miles convert at 65%
- People 3-10 miles convert at 35%
- CrossFit and Spin are most profitable offerings
- Referrals convert at 80% vs 40% for other sources
- Leads who visit pricing page are 3x more likely to convert

What They Need:
- Automatic prioritization: which leads are most likely to convert?
- Clear assignment: who should follow up?
- Different communication for different quality leads
- Visibility into lead quality
modules.assignment:
Build an intelligent lead qualification system that automatically scores leads, categorizes them by quality, and routes them appropriately.

Goals:
- Create a lead scoring system based on conversion factors
- Categorize leads by temperature/priority
- Assign leads to the right person
- Trigger appropriate follow-up based on lead quality
- Build reports to validate scoring works

Key Decisions You'll Make:
- Which properties do you need to track scoring and assignment?
- How should you weight different factors in the scoring?
- What score ranges define hot/warm/cold?
- How do you assign leads geographically?
- What should happen differently for hot vs warm vs cold leads?
- Do you need different email sequences? How many? What cadence?
- How do you prevent workflow conflicts or overlaps?
modules.testingRequirements:
Test these scenarios:
- Perfect Lead: Downtown Austin, CrossFit interest, referral source, visited pricing page
- Distant Lead: Outside Austin, basic interest, social media source
- Score Update: Start with low score, update profile, verify score recalculates
- Assignment Logic: Create leads from different states, verify correct assignment
- Sequence Exits: Enroll someone in a sequence, then convert them, verify unenrollment
modules.deliverablesAndPresentation:

- Assignment workflows

- Documentation explaining scoring logic

Present (20 min):

- Show a lead flowing through scoring and assignment
- Walk through different email sequences and their purposes
- Present dashboard and explain how to use it
- Discuss one edge case you discovered and how you handled it

modules.clientStory:
TechFlow Solutions - A New Client

TechFlow Solutions is a 15-person B2B SaaS company in San Francisco selling project management software to marketing agencies. They have two sales reps: Jessica (West Coast) and Michael (East Coast).

Company Background:
- Pricing: $3,000/year (small), $8,000/year (medium), $20,000+ (enterprise)
- Average sales cycle: 30-45 days
- Offer a 14-day free trial
- Key decision point: prospects need personalized demo

Current Marketing Funnel:
- Top of Funnel: Content downloads (whitepapers, guides)
- Middle of Funnel: Webinars, case studies
- Bottom of Funnel: Demo request or trial signup

CEO Sarah's Frustration:
"We get 40-50 leads weekly, but they're all mixed together. Someone who downloads our ebook gets treated the same as someone who requests a demo. We need different paths for different interest levels."

Sales Reps' Complaints:
- Jessica: "I'm in California but keep getting New York leads at midnight their time"
- Michael: "Half my demos are no-shows because people signed up but weren't ready"
- Both: "Trial users ghost us - we need better nurture during their trial"
modules.assignment:
Build a sophisticated multi-touch automation system that treats leads differently based on their actions, assigns them geographically, and nurtures trial users throughout their evaluation.

Goals:
- Create different paths based on entry point (demo vs trial vs content)
- Implement geographic assignment with time-zone awareness
- Build trial user nurture journey (14 days)
- Score leads based on B2B buying signals
- Track and report on different paths' effectiveness

Key Decisions You'll Make:
- What properties do you need for B2B lead tracking?
- How many different forms? What fields on each?
- How should you score B2B buyers differently than B2C?
- What's the right cadence for demo request follow-up?
- How do you structure a 14-day trial nurture? What happens each day?
- How do you handle time zones for assignments?
- What happens when someone takes multiple actions (downloads content then requests demo)?
- How do you prevent sequence conflicts?
- What reports prove this is working?
modules.testingRequirements:
Test these complete journeys:
- Demo Path: Submit demo form from CA, verify immediate assignment, check follow-up
- Trial Path: Start trial from NY, verify 14-day sequence sends correctly, test trial expiration
- Content Path: Download content from TX, verify slower nurture begins
- Path Evolution: Start with content download, later request demo, verify path changes
- Time Zone: Create lead at 11pm ET, verify notification timing
modules.deliverablesAndPresentation:
Prepare:

- Lead scoring for B2B context
- Territory assignment workflow
- Three distinct nurture paths (demo, trial, content)
- Deal pipeline(s)

modules.clientStory:
OutdoorPro Rentals

Meet Jack Thompson, owner of OutdoorPro Rentals in Boulder, Colorado. His business rents outdoor equipment - kayaks, mountain bikes, camping gear, climbing equipment - to individuals and corporate groups.

Jack's Current Disaster:
"I track my 50 pieces of equipment in a spreadsheet. Another spreadsheet for who's renting what. Another for maintenance schedules. When someone calls asking if we have a kayak available next weekend, I cross-reference three sheets. Last month I double-booked two bikes. I also forgot to do maintenance on a kayak and it leaked during a rental - customer was NOT happy."

Business Model:
- Individual rentals: $40-150/day depending on equipment
- Corporate packages: $500-2000/day for multiple items
- Equipment needs maintenance every 90 days OR after 20 rentals
- Some equipment is seasonal

What Jack Needs:
- Track each individual equipment item (serial numbers, condition)
- Know instantly: "Is bike #47 available on July 15th?"
- Automatic maintenance scheduling
- Link equipment to customers and rentals
- Block equipment from being rented when in maintenance
- See which equipment makes the most money
- Understand which customers rent what types of gear

Why Standard Objects Won't Work:
- Can't track individual equipment as Deals (deals are transactions, not assets)
- Can't track as Contacts (not people) or Companies (not organizations)
- Need custom objects: Equipment and Rental Agreements
modules.assignment:
This is your first custom object implementation. You're creating a system where multiple object types interact: Companies (customers), Contacts (renters), Equipment (gear), and Rental Agreements (transactions).

Goals:
- Design and build two custom objects with appropriate properties
- Create association architecture connecting all objects
- Implement workflows that update equipment status through rental lifecycle
- Build maintenance triggering logic (time-based AND usage-based)
- Track revenue at equipment level
- Create operational dashboard

Key Decisions You'll Make:
- What properties should Equipment object have?
- What properties should Rental Agreement object have?
- How do these objects associate to each other? What labels?
- How does equipment status change as rentals progress?
- How do you trigger maintenance based on two different conditions?
- How do you calculate and track revenue per equipment item?
- How do you prevent double-booking (or at least flag it)?
- What reports does Jack need for operations?

Think About:
- Multiple equipment items in one rental - how to handle?
- Revenue attribution when one rental has multiple items
- Maintenance needed during reserved period - what happens?
- Searching availability across date ranges
- Seasonal patterns affecting maintenance schedules
modules.testingRequirements:
Test complete rental lifecycles:
- Happy Path: Create rental, move through stages, verify equipment status updates, check revenue calculation
- Maintenance Trigger - Time: Equipment last maintained 91 days ago, verify trigger
- Maintenance Trigger - Usage: Equipment reaches 20th rental, verify trigger
- Damage Scenario: Return rental as damaged, verify status changes and tasks created
- Booking Conflict: Try to create overlapping rentals, document how you prevent/flag this
modules.deliverablesAndPresentation:
Prepare:

- Rental Agreement object with pipeline
- Association architecture
- 10 equipment records with varied data
- 5 test rental agreements showing different scenarios
- Status management workflows

modules.clientStory:
Elite Youth Sports Academy

Maria Rodriguez runs Elite Youth Sports Academy in Denver. She offers sports camps and training programs for kids aged 6-16: soccer, basketball, baseball, track & field.

Seasons:
- Spring camps (March-May): 8-week programs
- Summer camps (June-August): Week-long intensives
- Fall leagues (Sept-Nov): Competitive team play
- Winter clinics (Dec-Feb): Skill development
- Pricing: $200-500 per program

Maria's Frustration:
"I have 400 families in my database. Some have one kid, some have three. The Johnson family - Emma does soccer, Tyler does basketball, Maya does track. I want to know: Is this a 'soccer family' or a 'multi-sport family'?"

"When Emma registers for summer soccer camp, I create a deal. Six months later she registers for fall league - another deal. Now I have 2 separate deals and I can't easily see: This family registered for soccer twice, basketball once, track once. They're super engaged!"

"I want to reward my most loyal families, but I can't track: How many programs has this family done? How long have they been with me? Do they keep coming back?"

The Problem Deals Alone Can't Solve:
- Deals show transactions, not patterns
- Can't easily query: "Families who registered for 5 camps this year" vs "Been customers for 3 years"
- Can't segment: "Families who've done soccer but never basketball"
- Can't identify: "This family just hit their 10th registration - send thank you!"

What Maria Wants:
- Track every registration as a behavioral event (separate from deals)
- Score families based on engagement: 1 camp = casual, 3+ = active, 10+ lifetime = VIP
- Trigger special communications at milestones
- Identify cross-selling opportunities
- Build reports showing registration trends by sport, retention rates, seasonal patterns
modules.assignment:
Implement a behavioral event tracking system that captures rich engagement data beyond standard deals, and use that data to segment families and trigger intelligent automations.

Goals:

- Build event logging workflow triggered by deals

- Implement workflows triggered by event patterns
- Build analytics showing engagement trends

Key Decisions You'll Make:
- What properties should your Camp Registration event capture?
- What properties do you need on Contacts (kids) and Companies (families)?
- How do you roll up child data to family level?
- How should you score family engagement? What factors matter?
- What score ranges define casual/active/VIP?
- What events should trigger special actions?
- What cross-selling opportunities make sense?
- How do you identify at-risk families?
- What milestone celebrations matter?
- What reports show meaningful engagement patterns?

Think About:
- One family, multiple children - how to aggregate data?
- Child switches sports - does "favorite sport" change?
- Family registers frequently then stops - when do you intervene?
- Seasonal patterns - should scoring account for this?
- Event data vs deal data - when to use each?

modules.clientStory:
Elite Youth Sports needs automated age group assignment and sibling discount calculation.

Business Requirement:
When a camp registration deal is created, automatically:
1. Calculate child's age at camp start date
2. Assign correct age group (U8, U10, U12, U14, U16)
3. Check for sibling discounts (15% if multiple kids in same camp session)
4. Update deal amount if discount applies
5. Ensure action is idempotent (running twice doesn't double-discount)
modules.assignment:
Write a custom coded workflow action that handles this logic with proper error handling.

Goals:
- Build working JavaScript custom action
- Handle date calculations correctly
- Query for sibling deals appropriately
- Update deal properties
- Include comprehensive error handling
- Log actions for debugging
- Create documentation

Key Decisions You'll Make:
- How to structure the code (organization, functions, etc.)
- How to calculate age accounting for birthdate not yet occurred this year
- Age group assignment logic
- How to query for sibling deals
- Discount application logic and idempotency
- What errors need handling and how
- What to log for debugging/auditing
- How to document for another developer

Requirements:
- Must handle missing birthdate gracefully
- Must handle invalid camp dates
